content.description: <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 6 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x,” and the heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is negative 2. f of x is negative 2. Column 2. x is negative 1. f of x is 5. Column 3. x is 0. f of x is 2. Column 4. x is 1. f of x is negative 4. Column 5. x is 2. f of x is negative 1. Column 6. x is 3. f of x is 3." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.25ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.25ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Selected values of a continuous function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. What is the fewest possible number of zeros of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 2, comma 3, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
